document.title:
L 1
norms of products of sines

para.p:
A trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
is an expression of the form

Math.text: list@(((sum _ (k = - n)) ^ n)@(c _ k * e ^ (i * k * t)), c _ k) element-of C

para.p:
Using the identity
=
e
⁢ i t
+
cos t
⁢ i
sin t
, we can write a trigonometric polynomial of degree
n
in the form

Math.text: list@(a _ 0 + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(a _ k * cosine@(k * t)) + ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@(b _ k * sine@(k * t)), a _ k, b _ k) element-of C

para.p:
The trigonometric functions
cos
⁢ k t
and
sin
⁢ k t
,
∈ k Z
, are the building blocks for
⁢ 2 π
-periodic functions (cf. []). To formalize the idea of the size of a
⁢ 2 π
-periodic function and to formalize the idea of approximating
⁢ 2 π
-periodic functions using trigonometric polynomials, we introduce
L p
norms.

For
1 ≤ p < ∞
and for a
⁢ 2 π
-periodic function
f
, we define the
L p
norm of
f
by

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ p = ((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(f * t)) ^ p * differential-d@(t))) ^ (1 / p)

para.p:
For a continuous
⁢ 2 π
-periodic function
f
, we define the
L ∞
norm of
f
by

Math.text: (norm@(f)) _ infinity = (maximum _ (0 less= t less= 2 * pi))@(absolute-value@(f * t))

When I was working on this problem, I first found simpler weaker estimates that apply to a larger class of products.

para.p: Hölder’s inequality is the first tool for which we reach when we want to bound the norm of a product.

p.text:
For any sequence
a
, we have

para.p:
Hölder’s inequality [, p. 45, Theorem 2.3] (cf. [, p. 151, Exercise 9.9]) states that if
=
∑
= k 1
n
1
p k
1
then

As
= 1

n
1 n
, this implies that

Math.text: (norm@((F _ n) ^ a)) _ 1 less= ((product _ (k = 1)) ^ n)@((norm@(sine@(a _ k * t))) _ n)

para.p:
For each
k
,

Math.text: ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(sine@(a _ k * t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t)) = (1 / a _ k) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi * a _ k))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t)) = (1 / a _ k) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (a _ k))@(((integral _ (2 * pi * (j - 1))) ^ (2 * pi * j))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t))) = (1 / a _ k) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (a _ k))@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t + 2 * pi * (j - 1)))) ^ n * differential-d@(t))) = (1 / a _ k) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (a _ k))@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t))) = ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t)) = 2 * ((integral _ 0) ^ pi)@((sine ^ n)@(t * d * t))
(1 / a _ k) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi * a _ k))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t))
(1 / a _ k) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (a _ k))@(((integral _ (2 * pi * (j - 1))) ^ (2 * pi * j))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t)))
(1 / a _ k) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (a _ k))@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t + 2 * pi * (j - 1)))) ^ n * differential-d@(t)))
(1 / a _ k) * ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ (a _ k))@(((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@((absolute-value@(sine@(t))) ^ n * differential-d@(t)))

para.p:
Since
- log
is a convex function on
( 0 , ∞ )
, by Jensen’s inequality [, p. 44, Theorem 2.2] we have for any nonnegative function
f
with
<
∥ f ∥
1
∞
that

Math.text: - logarithm@((1 / (2 * pi)) * ((integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi))@(f * t * differential-d@(t))) less= (1 / (2 * pi)) * (integral _ 0) ^ (2 * pi) - logarithm@(f * t) * d * t

para.p:
and the two sides are equal if and only if
f
is constant almost everywhere (for continuous
f
this is equivalent to
f
being constant). Hence, as there is no sequence
a
of positive integers such that
F n
a
is constant,

in Theorem .

This section talks about measure spaces and mixing. These topics take repeated exposure to become comfortable with, but Theorem is a pretty result whose statement can be understood without understanding its proof. The notion of mixing is related to independent random variables, for which the expectation of their product is equal to the product of their expectations.

Let
X
be a measure space with probability measure
μ
. Following [, p. 21, Definition 3.6], we say that a measure preserving map
: T
→ X X
is
r
-fold mixing if for all

para.p:
If for each
r

T
is mixing of all orders.

T q
is mixing of all orders. This can be proved by first showing that the dynamical system
(
[ 0 , 1 ]
, λ ,
T q
)
is isomorphic to a Bernoulli shift (cf. [, p. 17, Example 2.8]). This implies that if the Bernoulli shift is
r
-fold mixing then
T q
is
r
-fold mixing. One then shows that a Bernoulli shift is mixing of all orders [, p. 53, Exercise 2.7.9]. Using that
T q
is mixing of all orders gets us the following result.

para.p:
It would be overwhelming for a reader without experience in ergodic theory to work out the details of the reasoning that we indicated above Theorem for why
T q
is mixing of all orders. In the following we explain a more understandable derivation of the case
= n 1
of Theorem . For a measure space
X
with probability measure
μ
, we say that a measure preserving transformation
: T
→ X X
is mixing (in other words,
1
-fold mixing), if for all
∈
f , g
⁢
L 2
( X )
we have
